channel.title: Vector Marketing - Are they worth the time?
channel.description:
So I got a letter in the mail. They're hiring student (People like myself) for full/part time jobs. Base pay: $15.00 I was told they [b]are not[/b] telemarketing. But I don't understand that because how do they make sales? (Also not a door-to-door company). Are they legit? What do they do exactly? The site says "We sell CUTCO® The World’s Finest Cutlery™". This job doesn't seem that fun but from what the receptionist said it's fun to work there?
Does anyone know about this company?

item.title: Vector Marketing - Are they worth the time?

This thread can be closed now

item.title: Vector Marketing - Are they worth the time?
item.dc:creator: @stewie0888 stewie0888
item.description:
@stewie0888 wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:1, topic:520290”]So I got a letter in the mail. They’re hiring student (People like myself) for full/part time jobs.
Base pay: $15.00
I was told they are not telemarketing.
But I don’t understand that because how do they make sales? (Also not a door-to-door company).
Are they legit? What do they do exactly? The site says “We sell CUTCO® The World’s Finest Cutlery™”.
This job doesn’t seem that fun but from what the receptionist said it’s fun to work there?

Does anyone know about this company?[/quote]

I get letters from them too. The job is knife salesman, nobody buys anything and the pay isn’t exactly what you think it is.

Read full topic

item.title: Vector Marketing - Are they worth the time?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Krackkid:

Move to Utah and I can get you a job at subway easy, also I was hired at petsmart with no previous pet store experience, although I did work and live on a farm o.o

Lol you know that’s tempting because I know a girl out there
I wouldn’t move states to possibly get a job lol.

item.title: Vector Marketing - Are they worth the time?
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“casey., post:22, topic:520290”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=638788.msg4306147#msg4306147 date=1369854506]
I don’t think you understand what those type of schemes are, because a company having horrible working conditions isn’t a pyramid scheme or a ponzi scheme. It’s just a company with bad working conditions, you don’t have to pay them money or anything
[/quote]

[quote]pyramid scheme
n.
A fraudulent moneymaking scheme in which people are recruited to make payments to others above them in a hierarchy while expecting to receive payments from people recruited below them. Eventually the number of new recruits fails to sustain the payment structure, and the scheme collapses with most people losing the money they paid in.[/quote]

Who do you think is getting the other commission for any sales that do occur? The mangers who hired the person and than the other higher-ups.
As we’ve established, it is a bad place to work because the majority of times you will not profit.

However, after looking at their website they now loan you the knives. This was not the case several years ago, so I suppose you are not losing the investment money.[/quote]A pyramid scheme implies recursiveness, from this it doesn’t sound like you can recruit other people just being a salesman. But you’re probably right about managers getting extra from who they recruit.

Read full topic
item.source: Vector Marketing - Are they worth the time?

item.title: Vector Marketing - Are they worth the time?
item.dc:creator: @gothic_queen casey.
item.description:
@gothic_queen wrote:

Read full topic
item.source: Vector Marketing - Are they worth the time?

item.title: Vector Marketing - Are they worth the time?
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“casey., post:20, topic:520290”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=638788.msg4306111#msg4306111 date=1369848589]
It’s actually not a scam, lol. They aren’t asking for investments or anything, and cutco is a legit brand by vector marketing. We owned some of the knives before.

However, it not being a scam doesn’t mean you should go for it, OP. A quick Google made it sound like it’s extremely difficult work to sell expensive knives nowadays.
[/quote]
Well the way the operate is extremely shady and is a pyramid scheme. It is set up for the majority of people not to make money fail(which I would call a scam).You are right in the fact that you can make money, but lets be real…how many people are actually buying kitchen sets that are over $500? Family and friends? If I remember, the way they worked was you made $15 for giving a demonstration(once again, I’d imagine a small amount of people actually get to do this), and if you do make the sale you get 5% commission. They were pretty savvy to family/friends sales as well, so doing this wouldn’t necessarily work.

Once people realize they are wasting their time, they quit. But guess what, vector profited of selling the trial knife set and it is onto the next.[/quote]I don’t think you understand what those type of schemes are, because a company having horrible working conditions isn’t a pyramid scheme or a ponzi scheme. It’s just a company with bad working conditions, you don’t have to pay them money or anything

Read full topic
item.source: Vector Marketing - Are they worth the time?

item.title: Vector Marketing - Are they worth the time?
item.dc:creator: @gothic_queen casey.
item.description:
@gothic_queen wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:16, topic:520290”]It’s actually not a scam, lol. They aren’t asking for investments or anything, and cutco is a legit brand by vector marketing. We owned some of the knives before.

However, it not being a scam doesn’t mean you should go for it, OP. A quick Google made it sound like it’s extremely difficult work to sell expensive knives nowadays.[/quote]
Well the way the operate is extremely shady and is a pyramid scheme. It is set up for the majority of people not to make money fail(which I would call a scam).You are right in the fact that you can make money, but lets be real…how many people are actually buying kitchen sets that are over $500? Family and friends? If I remember, the way they worked was you made $15 for giving a demonstration(once again, I’d imagine a small amount of people actually get to do this), and if you do make the sale you get 5% commission. They were pretty savvy to family/friends sales as well, so doing this wouldn’t necessarily work.

Once people realize they are wasting their time, they quit. But guess what, vector profited of selling the trial knife set and it is onto the next.

Read full topic
item.source: Vector Marketing - Are they worth the time?

item.source: Vector Marketing - Are they worth the time?

item.title: Vector Marketing - Are they worth the time?
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:17, topic:520290”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=638788.msg4306111#msg4306111 date=1369848589]

Its a ponzi scheme, maybe if you took the loveing time to google it instead of asking us you would know.

Source: When I graduated high school they did the same thing and contacted me. As did everyone who graduated my school. As did everyone who graudated the surrounding schools. As did they did years before, and most likely for years to come.

[/quote]It’s actually not a scam, lol. They aren’t asking for investments or anything, and cutco is a legit brand by vector marketing. We owned some of the knives before.

However, it not being a scam doesn’t mean you should go for it, OP. A quick Google made it sound like it’s extremely difficult work to sell expensive knives nowadays.

What I got from a google search was that they are bullshit, they expect you to get your own clients, and you have to buy a set of knifes for your self (also said they were like $300 lol). Someone said that they were driving for 45+ minutes (or miles?) a day, and ended up getting a check for only $45 in the end of the week.[/quote]sounds about right it’s bad enough the “interview process” takes about 4-5 hours…

Read full topic

However, it not being a scam doesn’t mean you should go for it, OP. A quick Google made it sound like it’s extremely difficult work to sell expensive knives nowadays.[/quote]
What I got from a google search was that they are bullshit, they expect you to get your own clients, and you have to buy a set of knifes for your self (also said they were like $300 lol). Someone said that they were driving for 45+ minutes (or miles?) a day, and ended up getting a check for only $45 in the end of the week.

item.title: Vector Marketing - Are they worth the time?
item.dc:creator: @Slave_Scyth Slave Scyth
item.description:
@Slave_Scyth wrote:

[quote=“xxxtilllyxxx, post:9, topic:520290”]Most companies offer their own car.[/quote]I sure hope you don’t mean delivery. I know of 0 delivery places that offer their own vehicle.

If you’re able to get a car, the delivery deal would be my suggestion as well. I averaged about $15/hour at a local place, and that’s on the low-end of what you can make delivering. They didn’t count my cash tips and so half of that was not taxed, either. You’d pay off any cheap car quick. Not to mention that pizza places are ALWAYS hiring.

Read full topic

item.title: Vector Marketing - Are they worth the time?
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

I went to their “training” class a while back when I was about 19. They pay good but in reality what it is is this…

-you go door to door
-you are scheduled tow ork you better be there
-hours are limited

not worth it.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“Rodgerwilco, post:7, topic:520290”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=638788.msg4305904#msg4305904 date=1369789758]
18. Just need a summer job, or one that will carry into following me into college etc.
[/quote]

Lifeguarding (little too late in the season to get hired)
Fast Food
Pizza Delivery (I recommend this, my buddy gets about 300-400 off tips a week + his pay check)[/quote]
No car. So delivery = no go.
I’ve tried Jack in the box, Mcdonalds, Subway, Burger King, Taco bell, KFC, and any other business in my area.
